points.content: Developed features for working with Facebook through a Shopify app. Works in Rails
Worked in a super hipster framework known as Ruby on Rails.
Documented and built components for moving to a new authentication system for internal tools.
Made multiple apps GDPR compliant, many in prerelease and including one with over 30 000 users.
Worked on small bugs and features for the Facebook Ads app.
Played a lot of foosball, in fact, played foosball daily. Earned a foosperson on the last day of work.
Designed a new CS curriculum with a focus on self-learning called Alpha, targeted at high school students.
Designed a new CS curriculum with a focus on self-learning called Alpha, targeted at high school students. Curriculum was designed with educators and was released into beta.
Used React, Django and MySQL to build a platform for coaches and students to track progress for the new curriculum. Implemented React into Django to migrate off Angular.
Added end-to-end testing with Cypress while working on small features and bugs.
Learned that end-to-end tests are very often flakey and a huge pain to update.
Taught skiing to a variety of ages and skill levels as a licensed instructor.
Started teaching after two years of volunteering as an apprentice.
Won the honours of signing a bent golden(no sparkles or glitter unfortunately) pole as an Instructor of the Week Award.
Among fifty winners of over 3500 contestants for two months of open source contribution for One Laptop per Child software. Worked in Python GTK and Javascript.
Won for two months of open source contribution for One Laptop per Child software. Worked in Python GTK and Javascript.
Merged 27 pull requests and committed 2636 lines of code, worked on translations and documentation.
Designed a new tshirt for the organization! No one wanted to put it in print because it was ugly. Oof.
Went on a fun trip to Mountain View where I got to meet some cute GCI winners. Proudly skipped a week of school.
Built a highlighter that sends highlighted text to mobile app in real time with React Native and Python.
End product was a $20 webcam taped to a can of redbull with a beer bottle opener as a 'nib'.

Won a set of Nintendo Switches, and the finalist prize which was basically just 'spend a couple hundred dollars however you want'. I chose to get new speakers, airpods and a brand new standing desk. I don't actually use the standing desk because I'm lazy.
Built a command line tool and Atom plugin that translates JS and Python between spoken languages.
Took home a third Nintendo Switch in less than a year. Kijiji history getting real sketchy.

awards.thing: Finalist and Best Use of Stdlib

points.content: Built a native Android app to play a location-based game based on a peer-to-peer SMS network.
Won a Nintendo switch. Also the project is what I claim to be the second most useless hack ever to make finalist at a hackathon. The first is a game where you guess if Trump's tweet is 'bullshit'.
Built a smart notetaker designed to integrate with drawing diagrams and doing math. Also recorded audio intelligently, though some would argue it to be unethical.
Built 'Faight', an online game where people can get AIs to compete by programming in any language. Supported Brianfuck.
Made the tallest stack of cups. Only won because our team had taller people.
It's a chemistry contest. Wow look a non-software thing.
Writes solutions to contest problems. Has authored some problems too.
Wrote and published some problems.
Helped organize logistics DMPG, an onsite contest with 200 attendees from the region.
Uses printer to print small items for home use and printing flow toys!
Collected nearly 30 species of carnivorous plants, including nepenthes, sarracenia, drosera, dionaea, utricularia and pinguicula
Grew plants from seed, leaf cuttings and had a custom built lighting and watering setup.
Primarily practices aerial hoop. I train for hours every week! I also do poi, silks, rope, trapeze and pole. I hope to get something to better document my training in the near futureâ„¢
I get really sad when I don't go to the circus space for too long <3.
Yikes this hackathon was literally the weekend in the middle of my exams.
Worked on scheduling, programming of mini-events and application review along with other tasks.
Worked on logistics for a hackathon that supported 550 amazing participants for 36 hours <3.
Personally brought in highly body positive fitness sessions and FREE MASSAGES for participants
Experience Lead for THacks 2, with 350 attendees. Managed 1200 applications, judging and workshops.
Organized workshops with Google and Mozilla, as well computing contests and children's events.
Organizes school dances, carnivals, and spirit days.
Builds software solutions, such as matchmaking apps, ticketing systems or websites.
Stopped hacking around 2018 because I like sleep. I still enjoy mentoring / giving workshops at hackathons!
Mentored at several hackathons, gave workshops and judged at others. You can find me probably at most hackathons I'm near!
16 wins and maybe counting?
Judged at Hack the Hammer and JAM Hacks 2. Gave a workshop at Hack the Hammer
Mentored at a lot of hackathons. For hackathons that have a system where the mentor is assigned to a team, all my teams have won something <3. They're smart cookies.

stuff.description: Google Code Jam to I/O Scholarship

points.content: Saw the Zucc irl.
Spoke about the applications of Wolfram Alpha in education, and how to used software to improve existing study tools targeted towards sciences.
'Applied Rationality' camp, 10 days with ~30 people, free boarding/sustinance. See their website for more info
